title: Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross calls reports that he was asleep during Trump’s UN speech ‘fake news’
text:
U.S. Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross on Tuesday rebutted reports that he was snoozing during President Donald Trump’s United Nations speech in Manhattan, referring to those stories as incidences of “fake news.”

“This is fake news. I wear hearing aids and, during President Trump’s inspiring speech, which covered in detail the entire range of significant issues facing the world, was concentrating on what was being said,” he said.

Video footage and images from both CNBC and CNN showed the 81-year-old Ross wearing headphones but appearing to nod off with his eyes closed for up to 15 minutes as Trump delivered what has been described as a subdued but hawkish address before the General Assembly.

This is not the first time Ross has been believed to have been caught napping during a Trump speech. Video from a Trump’s speech in Saudi Arabia in May 2017 showed Ross appearing to doze with headphones on, seated several seats away from the president’s daughter, Ivanka Trump. Other reports have described Ross as falling asleep during meetings.

For his part, Ross suggested in emailed comments, sent to MarketWatch via his representatives, that he had maintained a rigorous agenda in New York and was not ill. “Immediately following the President’s remarks, I attended bilateral meetings with the leaders of the United Kingdom and India, and, later in the day, will have follow-up meetings with officials from the United Kingdom and South Korea,” he said. “Additionally, throughout the entirety of the UN General Assembly, I attended events or am planning to participate in meetings with the governments of Pakistan, Poland, Egypt, Japan, Greece, and Vietnam.”

Trump, during his remarks to the UN on Wednesday, reinforced a long-held position that America comes first in international dealings. A two-year trade dispute between global economic superpowers China and the U.S. has rattled markets as it has disrupted manufacturing supply lines, while associated import tariffs have raised costs for producers.

“The future does not belong to globalists,” Trump said. “The future belongs to patriots.”

Trump reiterated his accusation that China is a currency manipulator and said that “for years these abuses were tolerated, ignored or even encouraged.”

U.S. markets, which have been sensitive to trade-related comments, appeared to soften amid the hawkish comments from the president near midday Tuesday. The Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, -0.53% , S&P 500 SPX, -0.84% and Nasdaq Composite COMP, -1.46% ended lower, with the tech-laden Nasdaq putting in its worst daily loss of the month.
description: U.S. Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross on Tuesday has rebutted claims that he was snoozing during President Donald Trump’s United Nations speech in Manhattan,...
